net.hudup.core.client

Interface Server

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.rmi.Remote
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    PowerServer
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Balancer, DefaultServer, ExternalServer, Listener, PowerServerImpl, SocketServer

    public interface Server
extends java.rmi.Remote
    Server interface defines abstract model of recommendation server. Server is responsible for creating service represented by Service interface to serve user requests. Server starts, pauses, resumes, and stops by methods start(), pause(), resume(), and stop(), respectively. Server interface must be implemented by programmer. Both server and service constitute a proper recommendation server (Hudup server). As usual, server creates one or many service (s) for serving incoming requests. Server extends Remote, which means that service supports RMI (abbreviation of Java Remote Method Invocation) for remote interaction in client-server architecture. The tutorial of RMI is available at https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/rmi.

    Server has six statuses as follows:
    • "started": Server started. If server has just started right after calling start(), it is in two statuses: "started" and "running".
    • "paused": Server paused. Server are currently in both "started" status and "paused" status.
    • "resumed": Server resumed. Server are currently in three statuses: "started", "resumed", and "running".
    • "stopped": Server stopped and so server is in "stopped" status.
    • "setconfig": Server is in setting its configuration. Sever must stop so that it can set its configuration. So server is now in two statuses: "stopped" and "setconfig".
    • "exit": Server exits and so server does not exist. Status "exit" is unreal.
    Some statuses are overlapped; for example, server is in status "paused" is also in status "started". When server changes its current status by calling methods such as start(), pause(), resume(), stop(), and exit(). Methods such as isStarted(), isPaused(), and isRunning() are used to query current status of server. Every time server change its current status, it notifies an event ServerStatusEvent to listeners that implement ServerStatusListener interface. Such listeners are called server status listeners, which must be registered with server by method addStatusListener(ServerStatusListener) to receive server status events. A server status event is removed from server by calling removeStatusListener(ServerStatusListener).

    Within client-server architecture, the popular recommendation scenario includes five following steps in top-down order:
    1. User (or client application) specifies her / his request in text format. Typical client application is the Evaluator module. Interpreter component in interface layer parses such text into JSON format request. Listener component in interface layer sends JSON format request to service layer. In distributed environment, balancer is responsible for choosing optimal service layer site to send JSON request.
    2. {Service layer} receives JSON request from interface layer. There are two occasions:
      • Request is to get favorite items. In this case, request is passed to recommender service. Recommender service applies appropriate strategy into producing a list of favorite items. If snapshot (or scanner) necessary to recommendation algorithms is not available in share memory layer, recommender service requires storage service to create snapshot (or scanner). After that, the list of favorite items is sent back to interface layer as JSON format result.
      • Request is to retrieve or update data such as querying item profile, querying average rating on specified item, rating an item, and modifying user profile. In this case, request is passed to storage service. If request is to update data then, an update request is sent to transaction layer. If request is to retrieve information then storage service looks up share memory layer to find out appropriate snapshot or scanner. If such snapshot (or scanner) does not exists nor contains requisite information then, a retrieval request is sent to transaction layer; otherwise, in found case, requisite information is extracted from found snapshot (or scanner) and sent back to interface layer as JSON format result.
    3. Transaction layer analyzes update requests and retrieval requests from service layer and parses them into transactions. Each transaction is a bunch of read and write operations. All low-level operations are harmonized in terms of concurrency requirement and sent to data layer later. Some access concurrency algorithms can be used according to pre-defined isolation level.
    4. Data layer processes read and write operations and sends back raw result to transaction layer. Raw result is the piece of information stored in Dataset and KBase. Raw result can be output variable indicating whether or not update (write) request is processed successfully. Transaction layer collects and sends back the raw result to service layer. Service layer translates raw result into JSON format result and sends such translated result to interface layer in succession.
    5. The interpreter component in interface layer receives and translates JSON format result into text format result easily understandable for users.
    The sub-architecture of recommendation server (recommender) is inspired from the architecture of Oracle database management system (Oracle DBMS); especially concepts of listener and share memory layer are borrowed from concepts "Listener" and "System Global Area" of Oracle DBMS, respectively, available at https://docs.oracle.com/database/122/index.htm.
    Version:
    10.0
    Author:
    Loc Nguyen

      • stop

        void stop()
   throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Server stops. After server stopped, it can re-start by calling start().
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if any error raises.

      • exit

        void exit()
   throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Exiting server. After server is exited, it is removed from memory and it cannot be started again.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if any error raises.

              throws java.rmi.RemoteException

      • addStatusListener

        boolean addStatusListener(ServerStatusListener listener)
                   throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Server has six statuses as follows:
        • "started": Server started. If server has just started right after calling start(), it is in two statuses: "started" and "running".
        • "paused": Server paused. Server are currently in both "started" status and "paused" status.
        • "resumed": Server resumed. Server are currently in three statuses: "started", "resumed", and "running".
        • "stopped": Server stopped and so server is in "stopped" status.
        • "setconfig": Server is in setting its configuration. Sever must stop so that it can set its configuration. So server is now in two statuses: "stopped" and "setconfig".
        • "exit": Server exits and so server does not exist. Status "exit" is unreal.
        Some statuses are overlapped; for example, server is in status "paused" is also in status "started". When server changes its current status by calling methods such as start(), pause(), resume(), stop(), and exit(). Methods such as isStarted(), isPaused(), and isRunning() are used to query current status of server. Every time server change its current status, it notifies an event ServerStatusEvent to listeners that implement ServerStatusListener interface. Such listeners are called server status listeners, which must be registered with server by this method addStatusListener(ServerStatusListener) to receive server status events. A server status event is removed from server by calling removeStatusListener(ServerStatusListener).
        Parameters:
        listener - the server status listener that is registered into this server in order to receive server status event represented by ServerStatusEvent class.
        Returns:
        whether add listener successfully
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if any error raises.

      • removeStatusListener

        boolean removeStatusListener(ServerStatusListener listener)
                      throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Server has six statuses as follows:
        • "started": Server started. If server has just started right after calling start(), it is in two statuses: "started" and "running".
        • "paused": Server paused. Server are currently in both "started" status and "paused" status.
        • "resumed": Server resumed. Server are currently in three statuses: "started", "resumed", and "running".
        • "stopped": Server stopped and so server is in "stopped" status.
        • "setconfig": Server is in setting its configuration. Sever must stop so that it can set its configuration. So server is now in two statuses: "stopped" and "setconfig".
        • "exit": Server exits and so server does not exist. Status "exit" is unreal.
        Some statuses are overlapped; for example, server is in status "paused" is also in status "started". When server changes its current status by calling methods such as start(), pause(), resume(), stop(), and exit(). Methods such as isStarted(), isPaused(), and isRunning() are used to query current status of server. Every time server change its current status, it notifies an event ServerStatusEvent to listeners that implement ServerStatusListener interface. Such listeners are called server status listeners, which must be registered with server by this method addStatusListener(ServerStatusListener) to receive server status events. A server status event is unregistered from server by calling this method removeStatusListener(ServerStatusListener).
        Parameters:
        listener - the server status listener that is unregistered from server and it no longer received server status event.
        Returns:
        whether add listener successfully
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if any error raises.
